source.raw_text:
A Trap Bar Deadlift (TBD) + Romanian Deadlift (RDL) combo targets the entire posterior chain (glutes, hamstrings, lower back) plus quads, core, and upper back, blending the TBD's more upright, quad-friendly hinge with the RDL's deeper hamstring focus, creating a powerful hip hinge movement that builds overall strength, especially when transitioning between the two variations or performing them sequentially for hypertrophy and strength. [1, 2, 3, 4]  
Muscles Worked 

• Primary Movers (Posterior Chain): Glutes, Hamstrings, Erector Spinae (Lower Back). 
• Secondary Movers (Lower Body): Quadriceps (more in TBD), Calves, Adductors. 
• Stabilizers (Core & Upper Body): Core (Abs, Obliques), Traps, Lats, Forearms (Grip). [1, 3, 4, 5, 6]  

Movement Patterns 

• Trap Bar Deadlift (TBD): A hybrid hip hinge and squat pattern, allowing for a more upright torso and greater knee bend than traditional deadlifts, increasing quad involvement. 
• Romanian Deadlift (RDL): A pure hip hinge, focusing on driving the hips back with minimal knee bend, creating a deep stretch in the hamstrings and emphasizing the posterior chain. 
• The Combo: You'll move from the TBD's upright start to a deeper hip hinge, mimicking the RDL's eccentric (lowering) phase, feeling the stretch in the hamstrings before driving the hips forward to stand tall. [2, 3, 4, 7]  

This video demonstrates the movement patterns of the Trap Bar Deadlift and the Romanian Deadlift: 
How the Combo Works 

1. Start with a TBD: Begin in the center of the bar, feet hip-width, handles grasped. 
2. Transition to RDL: Instead of a full squat, sit your hips back (like an RDL) to lower the bar, feeling the hamstring stretch. 
3. Drive Up: Explode up by driving hips forward and squeezing glutes, returning to the TBD's standing position. 
4. Lower with Control: Slowly lower the bar back down, focusing on the hip hinge and hamstring stretch to complete the rep. [1, 2, 7, 8]  

This blend builds strength through both the quads (TBD) and hamstrings/glutes (RDL) in a single, powerful movement, enhancing functional strength and muscle development. [1, 3, 9]
